Phoenix Learning Group (2008). ==External links== * {{official website|http://www.judychicago.com}} * [http://throughtheflower.org/page.php?p=40&n=3 Judy Chicago] on Through the Flower * [http://judychicago.arted.psu.edu/ Judy Chicago Art Education Collection] at Pennsylvania State * [http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:RAD.SCHL:sch00326 Papers, 1947-2004 (inclusive), 1957-2004 (bulk).] Schlesinger Library, Radcliffe Institute, Harvard University. * [http://digital.library.louisville.edu/cdm/landingpage/collection/ihq International Honor Quilt Collection], University of Louisville, Louisville, Kentucky. {{Authority control}} {{Feminist art movement in the United States}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Chicago, Judy}} [[Category:American contemporary artists]] [[Category:American feminists]] [[Category:American installation artists]] [[Category:American women installation artists]] [[Category:American women painters]] [[Category:American women sculptors]] [[Category:20th-century American painters]] [[Category:20th-century American sculptors]] [[Category:1939 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Artists from Chicago, Illinois]] [[Category:Artists from New Mexico]] [[Category:California State University, Fresno faculty]] [[Category:Contemporary painters]] [[Category:Contemporary sculptors]] [[Category:Feminism and the arts]] [[Category:Feminist artists]] [[Category:Jewish American artists]] [[Category:Jewish feminists]] [[Category:Jewish painters]] [[Category:UCLA School of the Arts and Architecture alumni]] [[Category:20th-century American artists]] [[Category:21st-century American artists]] [[Category:20th-century women artists]] [[Category:21st-century women artists]]

{{Infobox artist | bgcolour = | name = Carolyn Cole | birth_name = | image = Carolyn Cole.JPG | image_size = | alt = | caption = Cole speaks at [[Ohio University]] (2009) | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1961|04|24}} | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | education = Bachelor of Arts from the [[University of Texas]] at ''[[Austin, Texas|Austin]]
Master of Arts from [[Ohio University]] | occupation = Photographer | title = Staff photographer for the [[Los Angeles Times]] | spouse = | parents = | children = | website = }} '''Carolyn Cole''' (born April 24, 1961) is a staff photographer for the'' [[Los Angeles Times]]''. She won the [[Pulitzer Prize for Feature Photography]] in 2004 for her coverage of the [[siege of Monrovia]] in 2003, the capital of [[Liberia]].[http://www.digitalphotopro.com/profiles/carolyn-cole-running-in.html "Carolyn Cole: Running In"], ''Digital Photo Pro'', Mark Edward Harris ==Education== Cole graduated from [[University of Texas at Austin|The University of Texas]] in 1983 with a Bachelor of Arts, majoring in photojournalism. She earned her Master of Arts degree from the School of Visual Communication within the Scripps College of Communication at [[Ohio University]]. ==Career beginnings== She began her career in 1986 as a staff photographer with the ''[[El Paso Herald-Post]]'', a position which she occupied until 1988. She then moved to the ''[[San Francisco Examiner]]'' for two years, before spending another two years as a freelance photographer in [[Mexico City]], working with newspapers such as the ''Los Angeles Times'', ''[[Detroit Free Press]]'', and ''[[Business Week]]''. In 1992, Cole returned to being a staff photographer, working for ''[[The Sacramento Bee]]'', before moving to the ''Times'' in 1994. ==Recognitions== In 1994, the same year she moved to the ''Times'', she was recognized in their editorial awards for her pictures of the crisis in [[Haiti]]. The following year, she was recognized again, this time for her work in Russia. In 1997, she gained attention for her photographs of dying bank robber [[Emil Matasareanu]], who had been shot after a nationally televised [[North Hollywood shootout|shootout]] with police. Her evidence was used in the wrongful death lawsuit filed by his family. Her pictures also helped the Times win a Pulitzer Prize for its coverage of the event. Later that year, she was named Journalist of the Year by the [[Times Mirror Corporation]]. In 2002, she received the [[National Press Photographers Association]] Newspaper Photographer of the Year award for the first time. In mid-2003, Cole went to [[Liberia]], as rebels surrounded the capital, [[Monrovia]], demanding the resignation of President [[Charles G. Taylor|Charles Taylor]]. This trip was to earn her the [[2004 Pulitzer Prize]], "for her cohesive, behind-the-scenes look at the effects of civil war in Liberia, with special attention to innocent citizens caught in the conflict." She won the 2003 [[George Polk Award]] for photojournalism. In 2004, Cole was named both NPPA Newspaper Photographer of the Year for a second time, for her work in both Liberia and [[Iraq]], and the Pictures of the Year International Newspaper Photographer by the [[University of Missouri]]'s [[Missouri School of Journalism]]. This made her the first person ever to win all three of America's top photojournalism awards in the same year. During the year, she also spent time in [[Haiti]], witnessing the fall of the regime of [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]]. Cole has also received the [[Robert Capa Gold Medal]] from the Overseas Press Club in both 2003 and 2004,{{cite web|url=http://www.editorandpublisher.com/news/carolyn-cole-wins-another-major-photo-award|title=Carolyn Cole Wins Another Major Photo Award|work=[[Editor & Publisher]]|last1=DeFoore|first1=Jay|date=30 April 2004|accessdate=2016-06-16}} and won two World Press Photo awards in 2004.{{cite web|url=http://www.worldpressphoto.org/index.php?option=com_contact&task=view&contact_id=440&type=gallery&Itemid=146 |title=World Press Photo |publisher=World Press Photo |date= |accessdate=2012-03-31}} In 2007, she won the NPPA Newspaper Photographer of the Year.{{cite web|url=http://www.nppa.org/news_and_events/news/2007/03/bop13.html |title=Carolyn Cole Named Photojournalist Of The Year (Large Markets) |publisher=Nppa.org |date=2007-03-23 |accessdate=2012-03-31}} ==Issues with the law== In April 2000, Cole was arrested on felony charges for "throwing deadly missiles" at police during protests in Miami's "Little Havana" during the [[Elián González affair]].{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2000/apr/24/news/mn-22870|title=Police Say Staffer Threw Rocks|publisher=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=2015-08-27|date=2000-04-24}} Cole and the ''Times'' denied the charges, which were later dropped.http://www.rcfp.org/browse-media-law-resources/news-media-law/news-media-and-law-summer-2000/reporter-arrests-continue-o ==Kosovo, Afghanistan & the Siege of the Church of the Nativity== Cole spent time in [[Kosovo]] during the 1999 crisis, and in 2001, spent two months in [[Afghanistan]]. In 2002, Cole covered the beginnings of the prominent siege of Bethlehem's [[Church of the Nativity]], which had been occupied by Palestinian militants. Then, on May 2, she made a last-minute decision to join a group of peace activists who entered the building in solidarity with the Palestinians. Over the nine days that followed, she doubled as a news reporter for the Times, filing several stories. She was the only photojournalist in the building itself. The pictures she took earned her a nomination for the 2003 Pulitzer Prize.{{cite web|url=http://old.nationalreview.com/comment/comment-breitbart051402.asp |title=Undercover Photographer |publisher=Old.nationalreview.com |date=2002-05-14 |accessdate=2012-03-31}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.pulitzer.org/works/2004,Feature+Photography Cole's Pulitzer Prize-winning photo series, at pulitzer.org] *[http://www.latimes.com/news/local/photography/la-fg-haiti-hires-html,0,7123168.htmlstory "Haiti: Coping with the aftermath"], ''The Los Angeles Times'', 2010 {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Cole, Carolyn}} [[Category:American photojournalists]] [[Category:American women photographers]] [[Category:1961 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Artists from Los Angeles, California]] [[Category:Photographers from California]] [[Category:George Polk Award recipients]] [[Category:Pulitzer Prize for Feature Photography winners]] [[Category:University of Texas at Austin alumni]] [[Category:Los Angeles Times people]] [[Category:20th-century American photographers]] [[Category:21st-century American photographers]] [[Category:20th-century women artists]] [[Category:21st-century women artists]]

{{for|the British actress and socialite|Lady Diana Cooper}}
'''Diana Cooper''' (born 1964) is a contemporary artist who lives and works in [[Brooklyn]], [[New York]].  She is best known for her hybrid works combining drawing, painting, sculpture, photography, and installation.<ref name=Wei>Lilly Wei, "Line Analysis," Art in America, April, 2008</ref>

== Biography ==
Diana Cooper was born in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]], to the artists and teachers Ian Cooper and Faith Cooper.<ref name=Wei /> She earned her BA in History and Literature from [[Harvard]] (1986), and an MFA in painting from [[Hunter College]]  (1997).<ref name=ARTnews>Barbara MacAdam, "[http://www.artnews.com/2012/12/19/%C2%AD%C2%ADpink-and-red-and-nascar-too/ Pink and Red and NASCAR too,]" ARTnews, December, 2012></ref>  She is married to the writer and scholar [[Mark Lilla]].<ref name="ARTnews"/>

== Artwork ==
Though initially drawn to dance and choreography when young, Cooper turned to the visual arts after college and studied at the [[New York Studio School]],<ref name="ARTnews"/>  and counts [[Elizabeth Murray (artist)|Elizabeth Murray]], [[Lee Bontecou]], and [[Philip Guston]] among her influences.  She had her first solo exhibition in New York in 1997<ref>Roberta Smith, [http://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/14/arts/art-in-review-629111.html "Diana Cooper]," Review, The New York Times , February 14, 1997</ref> and has been represented in the United States by [[Postmasters (art gallery)|Postmasters Gallery]] since 1998.<ref>Peter Schjeldahl, "[http://www.artnet.com/magazine_pre2000/features/schjeldahl/schjeldahl3-12-98.asp Thanks for Painting,]" The Village Voice, March 17, 1998</ref> Her early works on paper and canvas were based on doodling,<ref>Ken Johnson, [http://www.nytimes.com/1998/03/13/arts/art-in-review-diana-cooper.html "Diana Cooper]," Review, New York Times, 1998</ref> while later work became more three-dimensional and incorporated sculptural elements in large-scale works and installations that evoked images of systems and technology.<ref>Shirley Kaneda and Saul Ostrow, "[http://bombsite.com/issues/83/articles/2545 Artist’s Choice: Diana Cooper]," BOMB, Spring, 2003</ref>  In recent years, she has explored the potential of digital photography for capturing abstraction in the lived environment.<ref>[http://www.cabinetmagazine.org/issues/39/ Artist Project / Wrong Place, Wrong Time], Cabinet, Issue 39, Learning Fall 2010</ref> Cooper has exhibited her work widely in the U.S., Europe, and China, and was the subject of a [http://www.amazon.com/Diana-Cooper-Beyond-The-Line/dp/1880353377 ten-year retrospective] at the [[Museum of Contemporary Art Cleveland|Museum of Contemporary Art in Cleveland]] in 2007.<ref>[http://mocacleveland.bandcamp.com/album/beyond-the-line-the-art-of-diana-cooper Interview with Margo Crutchfield], Museum of Contemporary Art Cleveland, 2009</ref>  She is a former [[American Academy in Rome|Rome Prize Fellow]] and has received grants and fellowships from the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation|Guggenheim Foundation]], [http://www.anonymouswasawoman.org/ Anonymous Was A Woman], the [http://www.bfny.org/ Bogliasco Foundation], the [http://sharpeartfdn.qwestoffice.net/ Marie Sharpe Foundation], the [[Pollock-Krasner Foundation]], [[New York Foundation for the Arts]], [http://iea.alfred.edu/ Institute for Electronic Arts] and other organizations. Her Percent for Art public art commission for the Jerome Parker Campus in Staten Island, New York was named one of the top public art works in the country<ref>Diana Cooper - [http://www.nyc.gov/html/dcla/html/panyc/cooper.shtml NYC Department of Cultural Affairs], website</ref> by Americans for the Arts in 2009. It was also featured on the TV special on Public Art in Public Schools.<ref>Lindsay Christ, “[http://www.ny1.com/content/143949/the-classroom-collection--part-5--artists-of-new-public-school-pieces-do-not-aim-low?ap=1&MP4 Public Art in Public Schools, feature,]” NY 1 Television, July 24–28</ref>

'''Kinuko Yamabe Craft''' (born January 3, 1940 in [[Ishikawa Prefecture]], [[Japan]]) is a Japanese-born American contemporary painter, illustrator and fantasy artist.

==Biography==
[[Image:061706 kyc drawing.jpg|thumb|Moon goddess pencil drawing by the artist]]
Kinuko Yamabe Craft was born in [[Kanazawa]], [[Ishikawa Prefecture]], [[Japan]] on January 3, 1940.<ref name="oxford birth location">{{cite book|first=Terri|last=Doughty|title=The Oxford Encyclopedia of Children's Literature|url=http://www.oxfordreference.com/oso/viewentry/10.1093$002facref$002f9780195146561.001.0001$002facref-9780195146561-e-0744|chapter=Craft, Kinuko Yamabe, - Oxford Reference|publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]|date=2006|accessdate=August 2, 2016}}</ref><ref name="isfdb birthdate">{{cite web|url=http://www.isfdb.org/cgi-bin/ea.cgi?25614|title=Summary Bibliography: Kinuko Y. Craft|publisher=[[Internet Speculative Fiction Database]]|accessdate=August 2, 2016|archivedate=August 2, 2016|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/6jT91mETT}}</ref> She graduated with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in 1964 from the [[Kanazawa College of Art]]. After graduating, she came to the United States in 1964 to study at [[the School of the Art Institute of Chicago]] where she continued her studies in design and illustration. A majority of her earlier work was for the editorial and advertising market. 

Craft illustrated the cover art of the older editions of Shakespeare's work for the Folger Library.  She has a passionate love of European fine art and draws on a deep knowledge of European art history in creating her work. She is most inspired by the works of [[Leonardo da Vinci]], the [[Pre-Raphaelites]], and [[Symbolist painters]]. Her work is done with a combination of artist oils and watercolor on clayboard gesso panels.

Craft has illustrated eight picture books (fairy tale and classic mythology) designed for children and young readers. Since the mid-1990s, she has concentrated her efforts on art for fantasy book jackets. Her art has included paintings for the book covers of many well-known fantasy authors such as [[Patricia A. McKillip]], [[Juliet Marillier]], and [[Tanith Lee]]. She has also designed opera posters, fairy tale books and painted cover art for many national magazines such as ''Time'', ''Newsweek'', and ''National Geographic''.

She has collaborated with many authors and worked with her husband Mahlon F. Craft and her daughter Marie Charlotte Craft. Her original paintings, drawings, and limited-edition prints are represented by Borsini-Burr Gallery in [[Montara, California]], and other galleries.

Her art has been licensed on calendars, posters, greeting cards, and other consumer goods. Her fairy tale books are currently distributed in the USA, other English-speaking countries, Europe, Greece, China, and Korea. She has received numerous awards for her work, including several gold and silver medals from [[the Society of Illustrators]], New York, NY. Ms. Craft’s work can be found in the collections of [[National Portrait Gallery (United States)]], the Museum of American Illustration in New York City, the National Geographic Society, and other corporate collections.

She has been nominated five times since 2001 as a Best Artist for the [[World Fantasy Awards]]<ref>{{cite web|author=World Fantasy Convention|year= 2010|title=Award Winners and Nominees|url=http://www.worldfantasy.org/awards/awardslist.html/|accessdate= 4 Feb 2011}}</ref> and won the World Fantasy Award for Best Artist in 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tor.com/blogs/2011/10/announcing-the-2011-world-fantasy-award-winners|title=Announcing the 2011 World Fantasy Award Winners}}</ref>

Craft has also lectured and given workshops at numerous art schools, universities, and organizations, including Art Center College of Art and Design, San Jose State University, Rhode Island School of Design, Philadelphia College of the Arts (2012), and more.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://kycraft.com/biography.html|title=Kinuko Y Craft Biography}}</ref>

'''Nicole Farhi, Lady Hare''', [[CBE]] (born 25 July 1946) is a French fashion designer and [[sculpture|sculptor]] born in [[Nice]], [[France]].<ref>[http://www.npg.org.uk/live/search/person.asp?LinkID=mp65139 National Portrait Gallery page for Nicole Farhi]</ref><ref>[http://www.designerhistory.com/historyofashion/farhi.html Designerhistory.com]</ref><ref>[http://www.style.com/fashionshows/review/F2012RTW-NCLFARHI Style.com]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.co.uk/news/2012/01/13/nicole-farhi---kelso-place-new-investor-opengate-sold|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|title=Farhi Change|date=2012-05-08|author=Lauren Milligan}}</ref>

==Early life and education==
Farhi is the daughter of [[Sephardic Jews]] from [[Turkey]]. She was born in France.<ref name="theguardian.com">[http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2009/sep/19/fashion-designers-fashion]</ref>

==Career==
Farhi started her career as a freelancer in Paris, before moving to [[London]] in the 1970s.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fashion.net/nicole-farhi|title=Nicole Farhi|publisher=fashion.net|accessdate=10 December 2015}}</ref>

In 1978, Farhi was employed by [[Stephen Marks]] on his [[French Connection (clothing)|French Connection]] label, to head up the company’s design studio in [[Bow, London|Bow]], East London.<ref name=FashCyc/>

In 1982, Marks assisted Farhi in launching an eponymous ''Nicole Farhi'' higher-end [[fashion label]] within the French Connection group.<ref name=FashCyc>http://www.fashionencyclopedia.com/Fr-Gu/French-Connection.html. Retrieved 2013-02-06.</ref> The label opened shops worldwide, as well as restaurants in London and [[New York]]; but the non-UK locations have since closed.<ref>[http://nymag.com/listings/stores/nicole_farhi/ Nymag.com]</ref>

On 15 March 2010, French Connection announced the sale of the brand and retail chains to [[OpenGate Capital]] for up to £5 million.<ref name="guardian">http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2010/mar/15/french-connection-sells-nicole-farhi. Retrieved 2013-02-06.</ref><ref>[http://www.londonstockexchange.com/exchange/prices-and-news/news/market-news/market-news-detail.html?announcementId=10410016 "Regulatory News Service link"]: "French Connection Group plc, Completion of Strategic Review, Announcement of Sale of a Business and Preliminary Results for the year ended 31 January 2010, released 15 March 2010."</ref> Administrators Zolfo Cooper were appointed on 3 July 2013, to advise on sale or restructuring of the remaining five UK shops and associated retail outlets located within [[Harvey Nichols]], [[House of Fraser]] and [[Selfridges]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-23164295|title=Nicole Farhi fashion chain enters administration|publisher=[[BBC News]]|date=3 July 2013|accessdate=3 July 2013}}</ref>

==Personal life==
Farhi and Marks' professional relationship resulted in a personal relationship, and the couple had a daughter, Candice Marks,<ref name="theguardian.com"/><ref>[http://www.heraldscotland.com/a-lady-and-a-vamp-1.836088]</ref> before separating. Farhi married [[British people|British]] playwright [[David Hare (playwright)|David Hare]] in 1992.<ref>[http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2354740/Fashion-chain-Nicole-Farhi-goes-administration.html]</ref>

She is a cousin of the writer and human rights campaigner [[Moris Farhi]].<ref>[http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/style/living/article157878.ece]</ref>

==Honors and awards==
In 2007, Farhi was appointed an honorary [[CBE]], and, in 2010, she was awarded the [[Legion of Honour]].<ref>[http://www.vogue.co.uk/spy/celebrity-photos/2010/09/22/nicole-farhi-legion-dhonneur-dinner]</ref><ref>[http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/newsbysector/retailandconsumer/10238688/Nicole-Farhi-collapsed-with-debts-of-almost-20m.html]</ref>

In February 2007, Farhi was a signatory to the declaration of the ''[[Independent Jewish Voices]]'', a new Jewish network, calling for an open and critical debate on [[Israel]] and criticising certain Jewish organisations' unconditional support of Israel.<ref>[http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2007-02-06/news/0702060152_1_middle-east-deputies-of-british-jews-fry]</ref>

{{about|the photographer|the film director|Lee Friedlander (film director)}}
'''Lee Friedlander''' (born July 14, 1934) is an American [[photographer]] and [[artist]]. In the 1960s and 1970s Friedlander evolved an influential and often imitated visual language of urban "social landscape," with many of his photographs including fragments of store-front reflections, structures framed by fences, posters and street signs.

==Life and work==
Friedlander studied photography at the [[Art Center College of Design]] in Pasadena, California. In 1956, he moved to [[New York City]] where he photographed [[jazz]] musicians for record covers. His early work was influenced by [[Eugène Atget]], [[Robert Frank]], and [[Walker Evans]]. In 1960 Friedlander was awarded a [[Guggenheim Fellowship]] to focus on his art, and was awarded subsequent grants in 1962 and 1977. Some of his most famous photographs appeared in the September 1985 [[Playboy (magazine)|''Playboy'']], black and white nude photographs of [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] from the late 1970s. A student at the time, she was paid only $25 for her 1979 set. In 2009, one of the images fetched $37,500 at a [[Christie's]] Art House auction.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/SHOWBIZ/Music/02/12/madonna.photo.auction/index.html?iref=mpstoryview |title=Nude photo of Madonna goes for $37,500 |date=12 February 2009 |publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref>

Working primarily with [[Leica Camera|Leica]] hand-held [[135 film|35 mm]] cameras and [[black-and-white]] film, Friedlander's style focused on the "social landscape". His photographs used detached images of urban life, store-front reflections, structures framed by fences, and posters and signs all combining to capture the look of modern life.

In 1963, [[Nathan Lyons]], Assistant Director and Curator of Photography at the International Museum of Photography at [[George Eastman House]] mounted Friedlander's first solo exhibition.<ref name="utpress.utexas.edu">{{cite web |url=http://utpress.utexas.edu/index.php/books/mcdnat |title=McDonald, Jessica. Ed. ''Nathan Lyons : Selected Essays, Lectures, and Interviews''. Harry Ransom Photography Series. |location=Austin |publisher=[[University of Texas Press]]. 2012. Pg. 10.}}</ref> Friedlander was then a key figure in curator [[John Szarkowski]]'s 1967 "[[New Documents]]" exhibition, at the [[Museum of Modern Art]] in New York along with [[Garry Winogrand]] and [[Diane Arbus]].<ref name="moma-press-release">{{cite web|url = https://www.moma.org/momaorg/shared/pdfs/docs/press_archives/3860/releases/MOMA_1967_Jan-June_0034_21.pdf?2010 | accessdate = 26 December 2014 | publisher = [[Museum of Modern Art]] | title = No. 21}}</ref><ref name="guardian-ohagan">{{cite news | url = http://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2010/jul/20/john-szarkowski-photography-moma | date = 20 July 2010 | accessdate = 26 December 2014 | first = Sean | last = O'Hagan | authorlink = Sean O'Hagan (journalist) | newspaper = [[The Guardian]] | title = Was John Szarkowski the most influential person in 20th-century photography?}}</ref> In 1973, his work was honored at the [[Rencontres d'Arles]] festival in France with the screening "Soirée américaine : Judy Dater, Jack Welpott, Jerry Uelsmann, Lee Friedlander" presented by Jean-Claude Lemagny. In 1990, the [[MacArthur Foundation]] awarded Friedlander a [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur Fellowship]]. In 2005, the Museum of Modern Art presented a major retrospective of Friedlander's career,<ref name="moma-retrospective">"[http://www.moma.org/visit/calendar/exhibitions/113 Friedlander]", [[Museum of Modern Art]]. Accessed 31 December 2014.</ref> including nearly 400 photographs from the 1950s to the present; it was presented again in 2008 at the [[San Francisco Museum of Modern Art]].<ref name="sfmoma-retrospective">{{cite web |url=http://www.sfmoma.org/exhibitions/exhib_detail.asp?id=304 |title=Exhibition Overview: Friedlander |location=San Francisco |publisher=[[Museum of Modern Art]]}}</ref>

Whilst suffering from arthritis and housebound, he focused on photographing his surroundings. His book, ''Stems,'' reflects his life during the time of his knee replacement surgery. He has said that his "limbs" reminded him of plant stems. These images display textures which were not a feature of his earlier work. In this sense, the images are similar to those of [[Josef Sudek]] who also photographed the confines of his home and studio.

Friedlander began photographing parks designed by [[Frederick Law Olmsted]] for a six-year commission from the Canadian Centre for Architecture in Montreal beginning in 1988. After completing the commission he continued to photograph Olmsted parks, for twenty years in total. His series includes New York City's Central Park; Brooklyn's Prospect Park; Manhattan's Morningside Park; World's End in Hingham, Massachusetts; Cherokee Park in Louisville, Kentucky; and Niagara Falls State Park. On the occasion of the 150th anniversary of the design for Central Park, the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] held an exhibition of Friedlander's photographs of that park and a book was published, ''Photographs: Frederick Law Olmsted Landscapes''.<ref name="met-olmsted">{{cite web | url = http://www.metmuseum.org/about-the-museum/press-room/exhibitions/2008/lee-friedlander-a-ramble-in-olmsted-parks | accessdate = 8 February 2015 | publisher = [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]] | title = Lee Friedlander: A Ramble in Olmsted Parks}}</ref><ref name="kennedy-nyt">{{cite news | url = http://www.nytimes.com/2008/01/03/arts/design/03frie.html?_r=0 | date = 3 January 2008 | accessdate = 8 February 2015 | first = Randy | last = Kennedy | newspaper = [[The New York Times]] | title = Compositions That Come Naturally}}</ref>

It has been claimed that Friedlander is "notoriously media shy".<ref name="kennedy-nyt" />

He now works primarily with [[Medium format (film)|medium format]] cameras such as the [[Hasselblad]] Superwide.

According to the colophon, "This third edition retains the new material of the 1998 edition except in its design, which returns to that of the original book."

{{notability|bio|date=December 2013}}
'''Elena Gaussen''' (previously known as '''Elena Gaussen-Marks''') is a [[London]]-based [[Portrait painting|portrait painter]].<ref name="website">[http://www.elenagaussen.co.uk/ Elena Gaussen], accessed 11 December 2009</ref> She was divorced from screenwriter and cryptographer [[Leo Marks]] in 2000.<ref name="grauniad">van der Vat, Dan [http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/2001/feb/02/guardianobituaries.filmnews Leo Marks], guardian.co.uk, 2 February 2001, accessed 11 December 2009</ref> Gaussen produces portraits and landscapes in a variety of media<ref name="website" /> including pencil sketches. She painted a portrait of [[Helene Hanff]] during Hanff's 1971 visit to [[London]], as documented in Hanff's 1973 book ''The Duchess of Bloomsbury Street''.<ref name="dutchess">ISBN 1-55921-144-X</ref> Gaussen's ''Portrait of the Artist'' was included in the 1992 Annual Exhibition by the [[Royal Society of Portrait Painters]].<ref name="catalogue">[http://www.therp.co.uk/pdfs/back-catalogues/1992%20Annual%20Exhibition%20Part%201.pdf 1992 exhibition catalogue], p19 (p18 in this version)</ref> Gaussen illustrated a 1999 book release of Marks's famous poem ''[[The Life That I Have]]''.<ref name="yours">ISBN 0-285-63532-8</ref>

'''Jill Gibson''' (born June 18, 1942) is an American singer, songwriter, photographer, painter and sculptor. She is mostly known for her collaboration work with [[Jan & Dean]] and for having briefly been a member of the successful 1960s rock group [[The Mamas & the Papas]]. She was also one of the main photographers at the historic [[Monterey Pop Festival]] in 1967.

==Early and personal life==
Jill Gibson was born in [[Los Angeles, California]] on June 18, 1942. She is half-English.<ref name="MelodyMaker">''Melody Maker'', July 23, 1966, p. 4, Vol. 41, "New Mama is definitely Jill"</ref><ref name="SongHits">''Song Hits'', November 1966, p.19, "Everybody Loves the Mama's & Papa's"</ref> Gibson attended [[University High School (Los Angeles, California)|University High School]] in Los Angeles. She is a former model.<ref name="MelodyMaker" /><ref name="SongHits" /> 

In 1975, she gave birth to a son, Mattia Borrani. Borrani has followed his mother's pursuit of a career in music and is the lead [[singing|singer]] and rhythm [[guitarist]] for the indie rock group [[Oslo (band)|Oslo]].

==Career==

===Association with Jan & Dean===
Jill Gibson was studying at [[University High School (Los Angeles, California)|University High School]] in Los Angeles, California when she met [[Jan Berry]] of [[Jan & Dean]] fame in 1959. The two were an item for the next seven years. Together they wrote over a dozen songs and through Berry, Gibson got more involved with the music scene. Eventually she began composing songs with other known songwriters such as Don Altfeld, [[George Tipton]] and [[Roger Christian (songwriter)|Roger Christian]], a Los Angeles-based disc jockey who also wrote with [[Brian Wilson]] of [[The Beach Boys]].

In 1962 Jan Berry decided to create a female answer to Jan & Dean called [[Judy & Jill]], featuring Gibson with [[Dean Torrence]]'s girlfriend Judy Lovejoy. Demo recordings such as "Come On Baby" (written by Gibson and Lovejoy), "Eleventh Minute" (written by Gibson and Altfeld), "Just For Tonight", and "Baby What's It Gonna Be" were cut and produced by Berry for [[Liberty Records]].<ref>Jan Berry's Nevins-Kirshner and [[Screen Gems]] contracts in possession of Mark A. Moore.</ref> Gibson performed most of the leads on these unreleased demos. Nothing major happened with the Judy & Jill recordings, however, and Gibson switched to providing background vocals on several Jan & Dean album tracks. Meanwhile, she studied [[visual arts]] at the [[University of California at Los Angeles]].

In 1963, Gibson appeared on the Jan & Dean track "Surf Route 101", and the next year she performed backing harmony on a song she wrote with Don and Horace Altfeld called "When It's Over" for a Jan & Dean album.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Richie Unterberger]] |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/as-easy-as-1-2-3-mw0000041963 |title=As Easy as 1-2-3 - Jan & Dean | Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |date=1998-08-11 |accessdate=2015-03-28}}</ref> She then recorded two vocal duets with Berry that she had written with Don Altfeld that year, "It's As Easy As 1,2,3" and "A Surfer's Dream".<ref name="jananddean-janberry.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.jananddean-janberry.com/main/index.php/disc/disc63-64|title=Jan & Dean - Official Jan Berry Website - 1963-1964|author=Administrator|work=jananddean-janberry.com}}</ref> The tracks appeared on 2 different 1964 Jan & Dean albums.<ref name="jananddean-janberry.com"/>

In November 1963 [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC television]] aired a one-hour special called ''Celebrity Party'' hosted by [[Dick Clark]] and [[Donna Loren]] that  included performances and/or appearances by Jill Gibson, Jan & Dean, The Beach Boys, Shelley Fabares, [[James Darren]], [[Connie Francis]], [[George Hamilton (actor)|George Hamilton]], [[Nancy Sinatra]], [[The Challengers (band)|The Challengers]], [[Johnny Crawford]], [[Deborah Walley]], among others.<ref name="Independent Press Telegram' 1963, p. 18">''Independent Press Telegram'' "Tele Vues." November 17, 1963,  p. 18</ref> It was sponsored by [[Dr Pepper]].<ref name="Independent Press Telegram' 1963, p. 18"/>

Gibson released her first solo recording in 1964, a cover version of her own song "It's As Easy As 1,2,3" backed with "Jilly's Flip Side", written by [[P.F. Sloan]] with [[Steve Barri]] and issued on [[Imperial Records]]. Jan Berry produced and arranged both tracks. She also sang backup on Jan & Dean's hit "Ride the Wild Surf." Gibson co-wrote the B-side single "He Don't Love Me" for [[Shelley Fabares]]' ''More Teenage Triangle'' LP in 1964 with Berry.<ref>''The Best of Shelley Fabares.'' (booklet). by Brian Gari. 1994. Rhino Records. pp. 6  & 7</ref>

In July 1965, a hit song Gibson had co-written with Berry and Roger Christian, called "You Really Know How To Hurt A Guy", peaked at number 27 for Jan & Dean on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] singles chart.<ref name="Top Pop Singles1955-2008">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Top Pop Singles 1955-2008|publisher=Record Research|year=2009|edition=12|page=489|isbn=0-89820-180-2}}</ref>

By the time Gibson sang vocals on Jan & Dean's last studio album, ''Jan & Dean Meet Batman'', in 1966, her personal relationship with Berry was ending; they had gone their separate ways by the album's March 1966 release but remained friends. Shortly after their breakup, Berry was involved in a serious motor-vehicle accident on April 12, 1966, which he survived.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/id/4614941/ns/today-today_entertainment/t/jan-dean-singerjan-berry-dies/ |title=Jan & Dean singer Berry dies – today > entertainment – Music |publisher=TODAY.com |date= |accessdate=2015-03-28}}</ref> Gibson often visited in the hospital during his long, difficult recovery. Later Gibson dated [[Lou Adler]], whom she had known since 1959 when he was the executive producer and manager of Jan Berry and [[Dean Torrence]]. Adler had recently separated from his wife, actress and singer [[Shelley Fabares]].

"Eleventh Minute" was briefly released in 1997 as the B-side of a 45 rpm record on the Maltshop Records label.  The licensed recording was soon withdrawn from sale (300 of the 500 red vinyl copies subsequently destroyed) due to questionable ownership of copyright and mechanical rights, as well as numerous label inaccuracies – most notably the performing artists are identified on the label of Maltshop 2 as "Jody & Jill". Furthermore, the A-side recording, "Come On Baby", was not the ballad demo offered to Liberty Records, but an up-tempo surf rocker by an unknown male singer and band.

On April 18, 2004 Jill Gibson was one of 400 invited guests who gathered at [[The Roxy Theatre]] in Hollywood, California, to celebrate Jan Berry's life and music at a tribute called "Jan Berry: A Celebration of Life". Other guests included Judy Lovejoy (her former singing partner), Dean Torrence, Don Altfeld (her former songwriting partner), Ann Marshall, [[Ryan O'Neal]], [[Nancy Sinatra]], Lou Adler, [[Lloyd Thaxton]], Diane Rovell and Ginger Blake of [[The Honeys]]. The night featured live performances of Jan & Dean songs performed by artists who had once worked with Berry in the 1960s. The event had been planned by Berry's widow, Gertie, and Al Nassar.

In 2008, Jill Gibson recorded the duet ballad "When It's Over" with [[Cameron Michael Parkes]] for the Berry tribute album ''Encomium In Memoriam Vol. 1''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jananddean-janberry.com/album/jb-album-artists.html|title=Jan & Dean: Jan Berry Tribute Album – Encomium In Memoriam Vol. 1|work=jananddean-janberry.com}}</ref> The song “When It’s Over” was originally written and recorded by Gibson with Jan Berry in 1964 that was issued as the B-side of Jan & Dean’s hit single "[[Sidewalk Surfin’]].”

===The Mamas & the Papas===
It was through Adler that Gibson met the rock group [[The Mamas & the Papas]], a highly successful band Adler produced in the late 1960s. Occasionally, Gibson would visit Lou Adler in the studio while he was producing the band, who had just begun work on a new album. Gibson found herself in the right place at the right time when the leader of the group, John Phillips, fired his wife, [[Michelle Phillips|Michelle Gilliam Phillips]], from the band on Saturday, June 4, 1966, for having had an affair with [[Gene Clark]] of [[The Byrds]].<ref name=Michelle86>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=Michelle|title=California Dreamin': The True Story of the Mamas and the Papas The Music, the Madness, the Magic that was |publisher=Warner Books|year=1986|edition=1|page=86|isbn=0-446-51308-3}}</ref><ref name=Hall102>{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Doug|title=The Mamas & The Papas California Dreamin'|publisher=Quarry Press|year=2000|edition=1|page=102|isbn=1-55082-216-0}}</ref><ref name=Fiegel203>{{cite book|last=Fiegel|first=Eddi|title=Dream a Little Dream of Me: The Life of Cass Elliot|publisher=Pan Books|year=2006|edition=1|page=203|isbn=0-330-48751-5}}</ref> Instead of the group breaking up, they asked Jill Gibson to join The Mamas & the Papas as their newest member "Mama Jill".<ref name=Hall103>{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Doug|title=The Mamas & The Papas California Dreamin'|publisher=Quarry Press|year=2000|edition=1|page=103|isbn=1-55082-216-0}}</ref><ref name=Greenwald137>{{cite book|last=Greenwald|first=Matthew|title=Go Where You Wanna Go: The Oral History of The Mamas and The Papas|publisher=Cooper Square Press|year=2002|edition=1|page=137|isbn=0-8154-1204-5}}</ref> Shortly after joining the band, The Mamas & the Papas, along with Lou Adler, left for [[Europe]] for several weeks to begin working together.<ref name=John149>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=John|title=Papa John: An Autobiography|publisher=Doubleday & Company Inc.|year=1986|edition=1|page=149|isbn=0-385-23120-2}}</ref>

Arriving in [[London, England]], Gibson, [[Cass Elliot]], [[John Phillips (musician)|John Phillips]], [[Denny Doherty]], and Lou Adler rented the top half of a large house in [[Berkeley Square]] to work in (the downstairs part was rented to [[Mick Jagger]] and model [[Chrissie Shrimpton]]).<ref name=John149/><ref name=Fiegel206>{{cite book|last=Fiegel|first=Eddi|title=Dream a Little Dream of Me: The Life of Cass Elliot|publisher=Pan Books|year=2006|edition=1|page=206|isbn=0-330-48751-5}}</ref> Over the next three weeks Gibson rehearsed with the group in London for the recording of the band's upcoming second album and for a few live shows.<ref name=Greenwald138>{{cite book|last=Greenwald|first=Matthew|title=Go Where You Wanna Go: The Oral History of The Mamas and The Papas|publisher=Cooper Square Press|year=2002|edition=1|page=138|isbn=0-8154-1204-5}}</ref> While in [[England]], the band had a series of business meetings, but still made time to party with [[John Lennon]], [[Paul McCartney]], [[Keith Richards]], [[Brian Jones]], and Mick Jagger at Dolly's (the private London rock club that catered to the stars).<ref name=John150>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=John|title=Papa John: An Autobiography|publisher=Doubleday & Company Inc.|year=1986|edition=1|page=150|isbn=0-385-23120-2}}</ref><ref name=Fiegel207>{{cite book|last=Fiegel|first=Eddi|title=Dream a Little Dream of Me: The Life of Cass Elliot|publisher=Pan Books|year=2006|edition=1|page=207|isbn=0-330-48751-5}}</ref> Upon returning to the [[United States]], the group, their manager Bobby Roberts, their attorney Abe Somer, and their label [[Dunhill Records]] officially fired Michelle Phillips on Tuesday, June 28, 1966.<ref name=Hall103/><ref name=John148>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=John|title=Papa John: An Autobiography|publisher=Doubleday & Company Inc.|year=1986|edition=1|page=148|isbn=0-385-23120-2}}</ref><ref name=Greenwald135>{{cite book|last=Greenwald|first=Matthew|title=Go Where You Wanna Go: The Oral History of The Mamas and The Papas|publisher=Cooper Square Press|year=2002|edition=1|page=135|isbn=0-8154-1204-5}}</ref> Jill Gibson was hired two weeks earlier, just before the band left for England.

Beginning in early July and continuing through part of August 1966, Gibson, Cass Elliot, Denny Doherty, John Phillips and Lou Adler recorded the band's second LP at [[United Western Recorders|Western Studios]] in [[Los Angeles, California]] with [[Bones Howe]] as the engineer. Fourteen tracks were recorded for the proposed second album,<ref>''KRLA Beat'', August 27, 1966, p. 16, "Mama's & Papa's Wax Unique LP"</ref> with twelve making the final cut. The first single "I Saw Her Again" was issued in late June but was recorded before Gibson was hired. The single peaked at number 5 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 on July 30, 1966,<ref name="Top Pop Singles1955-2008 p609">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Top Pop Singles 1955-2008|publisher=Record Research|year=2009|edition=12|page=609|isbn=0-89820-180-2}}</ref> while Jill Gibson was a member of the band. The group had been in the middle of recording their sophomore album when Michelle Phillips was fired.<ref name=Michelle91>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=Michelle|title=California Dreamin': The True Story of the Mamas and the Papas The Music, the Madness, the Magic that was |publisher=Warner Books|year=1986|edition=1|page=91|isbn=0-446-51308-3}}</ref> Once Gibson was hired they re-recorded the songs and also recorded new tracks with her at Western Studios.<ref name=Michelle91/> It was decided the album would be called ''Crashon Screamon All Fall Down'' and was scheduled for a late August release.<ref name="BillboardAugust">''Billboard'', August 20, 1966, p. 46, "The ABC of Fall Entertain"</ref> The American record-buying public had already ordered more than half a million advance copies of this album before it came out, and it was said to have been the most eagerly awaited record of that year.<ref name=Greenwald286>{{cite book|last=Greenwald|first=Matthew|title=Go Where You Wanna Go: The Oral History of The Mamas and The Papas|publisher=Cooper Square Press|year=2002|edition=1|page=286|isbn=0-8154-1204-5}}</ref>

Prior to Michelle Phillips having been fired, the band was photographed for the cover of their second LP inside the window frame of an abandoned house in the desert.<ref name=Hall104>{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Doug|title=The Mamas & The Papas California Dreamin'|publisher=Quarry Press|year=2000|edition=1|page=104|isbn=1-55082-216-0}}</ref><ref name=Fiegel204>{{cite book|last=Fiegel|first=Eddi|title=Dream a Little Dream of Me: The Life of Cass Elliot|publisher=Pan Books|year=2006|edition=1|page=204|isbn=0-330-48751-5}}</ref> This was soon changed by their label [[Dunhill Records]] who asked the original photographer [[Guy Webster (photographer)|Guy Webster]], to photograph Jill Gibson alone in exactly the same pose as Philips' had been in, and then to superimpose Gibson's image over Phillips'.<ref name=Fiegel204/><ref name=Hall105>{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Doug|title=The Mamas & The Papas California Dreamin'|publisher=Quarry Press|year=2000|edition=1|page=105|isbn=1-55082-216-0}}</ref> The record label was not satisfied with the finished product and therefore ordered an entire new album cover to be shot by Webster. Webster shot a new cover with Gibson, John Phillips, Denny Doherty, and Cass Elliot with a fan outside in a field of grass against a white picket fence.<ref name=Greenwald144>{{cite book|last=Greenwald|first=Matthew|title=Go Where You Wanna Go: The Oral History of The Mamas and The Papas|publisher=Cooper Square Press|year=2002|edition=1|page=144|isbn=0-8154-1204-5}}</ref> The label was pleased with this new album cover and it was used as promotion for the upcoming new LP inside of the music trade papers,<ref name="BillboardAugust" /> as well as on large billboards across the country.<ref name=Greenwald286/><ref name=Fiegel211>{{cite book|last=Fiegel|first=Eddi|title=Dream a Little Dream of Me: The Life of Cass Elliot|publisher=Pan Books|year=2006|edition=1|page=211|isbn=0-330-48751-5}}</ref>

A promotional campaign to introduce Gibson as the newest Mama soon followed, with articles in such publications as ''[[Newsweek (magazine)|Newsweek]]'' magazine, who did an article on the group where they referred to Gibson as "skeletal, modish, blonde and beautiful".<ref>''Newsweek'',  August 8, 1966, p. 78, Vol. 68, "Music/Under the Lemon Trees"</ref> Another article called "New Mama is definitely Jill" was published in ''[[Melody Maker]]'',<ref name="MelodyMaker" /> followed by a cover story on Gibson that was featured in ''[[KRLA Beat]]'' with the headline reading "Brand New Mama".<ref>''KRLA Beat'', July 23, 1966, p. 1, "Brand New Mama"</ref> The new Mama also did several television show appearances with The Mamas & The Papas to promote their latest single, "I Saw Her Again".

The Mamas & the Papas hit the road with Gibson for a few concert dates beginning on July 1 in [[Dallas, Texas]] (the Dallas show was supposed to be on June 18 but was postponed until July 1)<ref name=Greenwald139>{{cite book|last=Greenwald|first=Matthew|title=Go Where You Wanna Go: The Oral History of The Mamas and The Papas|publisher=Cooper Square Press|year=2002|edition=1|page=139|isbn=0-8154-1204-5}}</ref> and ending in [[Phoenix, Arizona]].<ref name=Hall105/> Other dates included [[Forest Hills, New York]] and [[Denver, Colorado]].<ref name=Michelle96>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=Michelle|title=California Dreamin': The True Story of the Mamas and the Papas The Music, the Madness, the Magic that was |publisher=Warner Books|year=1986|edition=1|page=96|isbn=0-446-51308-3}}</ref> [[Simon & Garfunkel]] opened for the band on some of these dates.<ref name=John152>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=John|title=Papa John: An Autobiography|publisher=Doubleday & Company Inc.|year=1986|edition=1|page=152|isbn=0-385-23120-2}}</ref> Things according to Gibson had gone smoothly, as if the fans had accepted her, and she was comfortable performing on stage with the group and enjoyed singing all of the songs in the band's 40-minute set.<ref name=Greenwald141>{{cite book|last=Greenwald|first=Matthew|title=Go Where You Wanna Go: The Oral History of The Mamas and The Papas|publisher=Cooper Square Press|year=2002|edition=1|page=141|isbn=0-8154-1204-5}}</ref> But according to John Phillips and other sources, the chemistry within the group was not there with Gibson.<ref name="Greenwald144" /><ref name=John153>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=John|title=Papa John: An Autobiography|publisher=Doubleday & Company Inc.|year=1986|edition=1|page=153|isbn=0-385-23120-2}}</ref> He decided in late August 1966, it would be best that Gibson be let go and that his wife Michelle Phillips be reinstated.<ref name=Hall116>{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Doug|title=The Mamas & The Papas California Dreamin'|publisher=Quarry Press|year=2000|edition=1|page=116|isbn=1-55082-216-0}}</ref> Michelle Phillips would admit that Gibson had sung well and had done a very good job as a member of The Mamas & The Papas.<ref name=Hall104/><ref name=Michelle96/>

According to Jill Gibson, fans did not scream out for Mama Michelle during every live concert with her; it occurred only once, at a show in [[Forest Hills, New York]], when a male fan shouted out, "Where's Michelle?"<ref name=Greenwald141/> ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine, who reviewed August 6, 1966 Forest Hills concert, said there were a number of hecklers in the audience.<ref>''Billboard'', August 20, 1966, p. 14, Vol. 78, "Talent/Mama's & Papa's OK, But Teens KO Show" by Hank Fox</ref>

Gibson was relieved to be free of the chaos that followed this supergroup, but she also felt betrayed by John Phillips.<ref name="Greenwald144"/> She had been told that her position in the group was permanent; it was not so.<ref name=Fiegel210>{{cite book|last=Fiegel|first=Eddi|title=Dream a Little Dream of Me: The Life of Cass Elliot|publisher=Pan Books|year=2006|edition=1|page=210|isbn=0-330-48751-5}}</ref> The band and their label [[Dunhill Records]] gave Gibson an undisclosed lump sum<ref name=Michelle100>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=Michelle|title=California Dreamin': The True Story of the Mamas and the Papas The Music, the Madness, the Magic that was |publisher=Warner Books|year=1986|edition=1|page=100|isbn=0-446-51308-3}}</ref> for her three-month stint as Mama Jill.<ref>''Life'', September 30, 1966, p. 84, Vol. 61, "Music/These are the Mamas" by Gerald Moore</ref> The album the group recorded with Gibson was pulled by the label to accommodate Michelle Phillips' return. No copies of ''Crashon Screamon All Fall Down'' featuring Jill Gibson were officially released to the public; the only copies circulating were pre-released copies.<ref name=Greenwald286/> The copies with Gibson are valuable collectibles today<ref name=Michelle104>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=Michelle|title=California Dreamin': The True Story of the Mamas and the Papas The Music, the Madness, the Magic that was |publisher=Warner Books|year=1986|edition=1|page=104|isbn=0-446-51308-3}}</ref> and it is believed that anywhere from ten to twenty thousand went out.<ref name=Hall105/> These promo copies are the ''Crashon Screamon All Fall Down'' cover with the white picket fence picture of the band.<ref name="BillboardAugust" />

With Michelle Phillips back in the mix, several tracks were re-recorded for the second album. The LP was renamed simply as ''[[The Mamas & the Papas (album)|The Mamas & the Papas]]'' and it hit the stores in September 1966, with Michelle's image on the cover.<ref name="The Billboard Book of Gold and Platinum Records">{{cite book|last=White|first=Adam|title=The Billboard Book of Gold and Platinum Records|publisher=Billboard Books|year=1990|edition=1|page=139|isbn= 0-8230-7547-8}}</ref> In 2002, Jill Gibson claimed that she recorded ten of the tracks for the second album,<ref name=Greenwald142>{{cite book|last=Greenwald|first=Matthew|title=Go Where You Wanna Go: The Oral History of The Mamas and The Papas|publisher=Cooper Square Press|year=2002|edition=1|page=142|isbn=0-8154-1204-5}}</ref> while Lou Adler claimed that same year she recorded only six of the songs, one being "Trip, Stumble and Fall".<ref name="Greenwald139" /> Session sheets of the actual recording dates state that Jill Gibson recorded seven songs. In 2006, Gibson said she still believed her voice remained on many of the songs.<ref name=Fiegel211/> Michelle Phillips claimed she had no idea who sang on the album,<ref name="Greenwald142" /> while author Matthew Greenwald confirmed in his book that Jill Gibson recorded part of the LP and did, in fact, appear on several of the final tracks of the final released version.<ref name=Greenwald286/> The LP was certified Gold and peaked at number 4 on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] Albums Chart without Gibson receiving a Gold copy herself.<ref name="The Billboard Book of Gold and Platinum Records"/><ref name="Top Pop Albums 1955-1996 p477">{{cite book|last=Whitburn|first=Joel|title=Top Pop Albums 1955-1996|publisher=Hal Leonard Publishing Corporation|year=1996|edition=4|page=477|isbn=0-89820-117-9}}</ref> A second single (not featuring Gibson), "Words of Love", was released from the LP and peaked at number 5 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 in late 1966.<ref name="Top Pop Singles1955-2008 p609"/> The third single "[[Dancing In the Street]]" also did not feature Gibson. The fourth and final single from the album was "[[Dancing Bear]]" featuring Gibson and it peaked at number 51 on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100.<ref name="Top Pop Singles1955-2008 p609"/>  "Dancing Bear" was released in 1967, a year after it was recorded.<ref name="Top Pop Singles1955-2008 p609"/>

After having been ejected from The Mamas & the Papas, Gibson wrote the songs "I've Got A Feeling For Love" and "How Can I Be Down" with producer [[Gary Zekley]] for the psychedelic band [[The Yellow Balloon (band)|The Yellow Balloon]]; Gibson did background vocals for the band's one eponymous record. She also co-produced in 1966 with Don Altfeld a cover version of the [[Bo Diddley]] song "[[Who Do You Love? (Bo Diddley song)|Who Do You Love?]]" for the [[blues]]-[[rock (music)|rock]] group [[The Woolies]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Jill+Gibson#t=Credits_Production&q=&p=1 |title=Jill Gibson Discography at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date=1942-06-18 |accessdate=2015-03-28}}</ref>

In 2002, Gibson's past as a singing former Mama came briefly full circle when she recorded a cover version of "[[California Dreamin' (song)|California Dreamin']]" with [[San Francisco]] singer-guitarist [[Ace Andres]] for his ''Cowboy Hat Blues'' album. On this version of her former band's pop hit, the song was turned into a hard rock song.

===Photographer===
Around her time with the Mamas & the Papas, Gibson returned to photography, which she had begun to take seriously back in 1965 when she met photojournalist [[Ralph Gibson]] (no relation). During this same period, Gibson studied with [[Edmund Teske]], a photographer working with the technique of [[solarization]].

In June 1967 Gibson attended the first ever [[Monterey Pop Festival|Monterey International Pop Festival]] with [[Lou Adler]], where she was an invited member of the press.<ref name="rockandrollgallery.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.rockandrollgallery.com/jill_gibson.html|title=Rock and Roll Gallery .com - JILL GIBSON  Bio|work=rockandrollgallery.com}}</ref> Over this three-day period in sunny [[Monterey, California]], she photographed nearly every act on the bill, and her photographs of celebrities such as [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[Janis Joplin]], [[Jefferson Airplane]], the Mamas & Papas, and [[Brian Jones]] have been published around the world.<ref name="rockandrollgallery.com"/> One of Gibson's photos of Jimi Hendrix made the front cover of ''[[Rolling Stone (magazine)|Rolling Stone]]'' magazine.<ref>''Rolling Stone'', September 18, 2003, cover, Issue #931</ref> Gibson can be seen twice in the film version of this festival, ''[[Monterey Pop]]'', by [[D.A. Pennebaker]].

Jill Gibson took the photographs for the [[psychedelic rock]] group [[Fever Tree (rock band)|Fever Tree]]'s self-titled debut album cover and its liner pictures for the band's 1968 LP released on  [[Uni Records]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/artist/Jill+Gibson#t=Credits_Visual&q=&p=1 |title=Jill Gibson Discography at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date=1942-06-18 |accessdate=2015-03-28}}</ref>

===Painter===
Gibson and Adler would break up as a couple in late 1967.<ref name=Michelle171>{{cite book|last=Phillips|first=Michelle|title=California Dreamin': The True Story of the Mamas and the Papas The Music, the Madness, the Magic that was |publisher=Warner Books|year=1986|edition=1|page=171|isbn=0-446-51308-3}}</ref> After briefly dating [[Elmer Valentine]], owner of the [[Whiskey A Go-Go]] in Los Angeles,<ref name=Hall134>{{cite book|last=Hall|first=Doug|title=The Mamas & The Papas California Dreamin'|publisher=Quarry Press|year=2000|edition=1|page=134|isbn=1-55082-216-0}}</ref> Gibson went to New York City to study art at the Art Student's League with classical artist Frank Mason. After two years there, and a short stint in  New Mexico, she left for [[Florence, Italy]] in 1970. For the next five and a half years Gibson painted while living in the Tuscan hills, studying briefly at [[The Simi Studio]] in Florence before returning briefly to California in 1973. On that return visit Jill Gibson made her American debut as a painter where her art was showcased for the first time at the [[DeVorzon Gallery]] in [[Hollywood]] for a week, and such guests as [[Jack Nicholson]], [[Roman Polanski]], Lou Adler, and Michelle Phillips were in attendance.<ref>''Rolling Stone'', January 31, 1974, p. 24, Issue #153, "Random Notes"</ref> Lou Adler purchased an original Gibson painting for $450 at the time while Nicholson also purchased two originals.<ref>''Rolling Stone'', January 31, 1974, p.24, Issue #153, "Random Notes"</ref>

Jill Gibson's developing style as an artist is influenced by her interest in Renaissance art, nature, and the feminine. Many of her original art works are in the private collections of [[Max Factor]], [[Guy Webster (photographer)|Guy Webster]], [[Michael Savage (commentator)|Michael Savage]], [[The Seattle Museum]], [[Jack Nicholson]], and a fifteen-foot photo montage in [[The Los Angeles Free Clinic]].

Today, Jill Gibson is a full-time artist with her own studio, Gibson Artworks, in [[Marin County, California|Marin]]. Over the last twenty-five years her art work has been displayed in galleries in [[Italy]], the [[Netherlands]], [[Germany]], and in the US.

Her paintings, sculptures, [[photography]], planters, plaques, fountains, and bowls can be viewed on her official website. She divides her time between her homes in [[Oakland, California|Oakland]], [[Los Angeles]], and [[San Mateo Rio Hondo]], [[Oaxaca]], Mexico.

'''Nancy''' "'''Nan'''" '''Goldin''' (born September 12, 1953) is an [[People of the United States|American]] [[photographer]]. She lives and works in [[New York City]], [[Berlin]], and [[Paris]].<ref name="gagosian.com">[http://www.gagosian.com/exhibitions/nan-goldin--march-21-2014 Nan Goldin: Scopophilia, March 21 - May 24, 2014] [[Gagosian Gallery]], Rome.</ref> She is known for her work, which usually features LGBT-related themes, images or public figures.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Burton|first1=Johanna|title=Nan Goldin|url=http://search.proquest.com/docview/914170687?accountid=14784&rfr_id=info%3Axri%2Fsid%3Aprimo|accessdate=Jan 2016}}</ref>

==Life and work==
[[File:Ballad of Sexual Dependency.jpg|thumb|''The Ballad of Sexual Dependency'' (1986). The image on the cover is "Nan and Brian in Bed" (1981).]]
[[File:The Hug.jpg|thumb|upright|Nan Goldin, ''The Hug, NYC'', 1980, cibachrome, 40 x 30 inches]]
[[File:Misty and Jimmy.jpg|thumb|Nan Goldin, ''Misty and Jimmy Paulette in a Taxi, NYC'', 1991, 30 x 40 inches]]
Goldin was born in [[Washington, D.C.]], and grew up in the [[Boston]] suburb of [[Lexington, Massachusetts|Lexington]], to middle-class [[Jewish]] parents. Goldin’s father worked in broadcasting, and served as the chief economist for the [[Federal Communications Commission]].<ref>Deborah Solomon (October 9, 1996), [http://online.wsj.com/article/SB844810967532358500.html# Nan Goldin: Scenes From the Edge] ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.</ref> After attending the nearby Lexington High School, Goldin left home at 13-14. She enrolled at the Satya Community School in [[Lincoln, Massachusetts|Lincoln]], where a teacher, philosopher [[Rollo May]]’s daughter introduced her to the camera in 1968. Goldin was then fifteen years old. Her early influences were [[Andy Warhol]]'s early films, [[Federico Fellini]], [[Jack Smith (film director)|Jack Smith]], French and Italian Vogue, [[Guy Bourdin]] and [[Helmut Newton]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Westfall|first1=Stephen|title=Nan Goldin|url=http://bombmagazine.org/article/1476/nan-goldin|website=BOMB Magazine|publisher=BOMB Magazine|accessdate=23 October 2015|format=Interview|date=1991}}</ref>

Her first solo show, held in [[Boston]] in 1973, was based on her photographic journeys among the city's [[gay men|gay]] and [[transsexual]] communities, to which she had been introduced by her friend [[David Armstrong (photographer)|David Armstrong]]. While living in downtown Boston at age 18, Goldin “fell in with the drag queens,” living with them and photographing them.<ref name="Westfall, Stephen 1991">Westfall, Stephen. "The Ballad of Nan Goldin." BOMB No. 37 (1991): 27-31.JSTOR. Web. 03 
Mar. 2015.</ref> Unlike some photographers who were interested in psychoanalyzing or exposing the queens, Goldin admired and respected their sexuality. Goldin said, “My desire was to show them as a third gender, as another sexual option, a gender option. And to show them with a lot of respect and love, to kind of glorify them because I really admire people who can recreate themselves and manifest their fantasies publicly. I think it’s brave”.<ref name="Westfall, Stephen 1991"/> Goldin admitted to being romantically in love with a queen during this period of her life in a Q&A with “BOMB,” “I remember going through a psychology book trying to find something about it when I was nineteen. There was one little chapter about it in an abnormal psych book that made it sound so… I don’t know what they ascribed it to, but it was so bizarre. And that’s where I was at that time in my life. I lived with them; it was my whole focus. Everything I did -- that’s who I was all the time. And that’s who I wanted to be”.<ref name="Westfall, Stephen 1991"/> Goldin describes her life as being completely immersed in the queens’. However, after she went to the school of Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, her professors told her to go back and photograph queens again, Goldin admitted her work was not the same as when she had lived with them. 
Goldin graduated from the [[School of the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston]]/[[Tufts University]] in 1977/1978, where she had worked mostly with [[Cibachrome]] prints. Her work from this period is associated with the [[Boston School (photography)|Boston School]] of photography.<ref>{{cite web|title=Emotions and Relations: Photographs by David Armstrong, Nan Goldin, Philip Lorca DiCorcis, Mark Morrisroe, and Jack Pierson |url=http://www.photoeye.com/bookstore/citation.cfm?catalog=TD034&i=&i2= |website=photo-eye |publisher=Taschen |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150425162245/http://www.photoeye.com/bookstore/citation.cfm?catalog=TD034&i=&i2= |archivedate=April 25, 2015 }}</ref>

Following graduation, Goldin moved to [[New York City]]. She began documenting the [[post-punk]] new-wave music scene, along with the city's vibrant, post-[[Stonewall riots|Stonewall]] [[gay]] subculture of the late 1970s and early 1980s. She was drawn especially to the hard-drug subculture of the [[Bowery]] neighborhood; these photographs, taken between 1979 and 1986, form her famous work ''[[The Ballad of Sexual Dependency]]'' — a title taken from a song in [[Bertolt Brecht]]'s ''[[Threepenny Opera]]''.<ref>Brecht, Bertolt. "Three Penny Opera." Act II, song 12.</ref> Published with help from [[Marvin Heiferman]], Mark Holborn, and Suzanne Fletcher, these [[snapshot aesthetic]] images depict drug use, violent, aggressive couples and autobiographical moments. In her foreword to the book she describes it as a “diary [she] lets people read” of people she referred to as her “tribe”. The photographs show a transition through Goldin’s travels and her life.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Goldin|first1=Nan|last2=Heiferman|first2=Marvin|last3=Holborn|first3=Mark|last4=Fletcher|first4=Suzanne|title=The ballad of sexual dependency|date=2012|publisher=Aperture Foundation|location=New York City|isbn=978-1-59711-208-6}}</ref> Most of her ''Ballad'' subjects were dead by the 1990s, lost either to [[drug overdose]] or [[AIDS]]; this tally included  close friends and often-photographed subjects [[Greer Lankton]] and [[Cookie Mueller]].<ref>Curley, Mallory. ''A Cookie Mueller Encyclopedia'', Randy Press, 2010.</ref> In 2003, [[The New York Times]] nodded to the work's impact, explaining  Goldin had "forged a genre, with photography as influential as any in the last twenty years."<ref>Tillman, Lynne. The New York Times. "A New Chapter of Nan Goldin's Diary." 16 November 2003.</ref> In addition to ''Ballad,'' she combined her Bowery pictures in two other series: ''I'll Be Your Mirror'' (from a song on [[The Velvet Underground]]'s ''[[The Velvet Underground & Nico]]'' album) and ''All By Myself.''

Goldin's work is most often presented in the form of a [[slideshow]], and has been shown at film festivals; her most famous being a 45-minute show in which 800 pictures are displayed. The main themes of her early pictures are love, gender, domesticity, and sexuality; these frames are usually shot with [[available light]]. She has affectionately documented women looking in mirrors, girls in bathrooms and barrooms, drag queens, sexual acts, and the culture of obsession and dependency. The images are viewed like a private journal made public.<ref>{{citation | title= Nan Goldin at Pa. Academy of Fine Arts | publisher=BLOUINARTINFO  | date= September 11, 2007 | url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/9149/nan-goldin-at-pa-academy-of-fine-arts | accessdate=2008-04-23 }}</ref> In the book ''Auto-Focus'', her photographs are described as a way to “learn the stories and intimate details of those closest to her”. It speaks of her uncompromising manner and style when photographing acts such as drug use, sex, violence, arguments, and traveling. It references one of Goldin’s famous photographs 'Nan One Month After Being Battered, 1984' as an iconic image which she uses to reclaim her identity and her life.<ref>{{cite book|last=Bright|first=Susan|title=Auto focus : the self-portrait in contemporary photography|year=2010|publisher=Monacelli Press|location=[New York]|isbn=978-1-58093-300-1|edition=1st American}}</ref>

Goldin's work since 1995 has included a wide array of subject matter: collaborative book projects with Japanese photographer [[Nobuyoshi Araki]]; New York City skylines; uncanny landscapes (notably of people in water); her lover, Siobhan; and babies, parenthood and family life.

In 2002, her hand was injured in a fall, and she currently retains less ability to turn it than in the past.{{citation needed|date=May 2014}}
[[File:Christmas at the other side.jpg|thumb|left|Nan Goldin, ''Christmas at the Other Side, Boston'', 1972, gelatin-silver print, 16 x 20 inches]]

In 2006, her exhibition, ''Chasing a Ghost,'' opened in New York. It was the first installation by her to include moving pictures, a fully narrative score, and voiceover, and included the three-screen slide and video presentation ''Sisters, Saints, & Sybils'' which has been described as disturbing.{{citation needed|date=June 2014}} The work involved her sister Barbara's suicide and how she coped through production of numerous images and narratives. Her works are developing more and more into cinemaesque features, exemplifying her gravitation towards working with films.<ref name="NGI">{{citation | title=Nan Goldin | author=Robert Ayers | publisher=BLOUINARTINFO  | date= March 27, 2006 | url=http://www.blouinartinfo.com/artists/72685-nan-goldin| accessdate=2008-04-23 }}</ref>

Goldin has undertaken commercial fashion photography – for Australian label Scanlan & Theodore's spring/summer 2010 campaign, shot with model [[Erin Wasson]]; for Italian luxury label [[Bottega Veneta]]'s spring/summer 2010 campaign with models [[Sean O'Pry]] and Anya Kazakova, evoking memories of her ''Ballad of Sexual Dependency'';<ref>Ann Binlot (January 3, 2012), [http://www.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/754977/bottega-veneta-taps-jack-pierson-for-latest-arty-ad-campaign Bottega Veneta Taps Jack Pierson for Latest Arty Ad Campaign] ''BLOUINARTINFO''.</ref> for shoemaker [[Jimmy Choo]] in 2011 with model [[Linda Vojtova]];<ref>Ann Binlot (October 18, 2011), [http://www.blouinartinfo.com/visual-arts/article/38892-the-ballad-of-shoe-dependency-nan-goldin-shoots-a-new-ad-campaign-for-jimmy-choo The Ballad of Shoe Dependency: Nan Goldin Shoots a New Ad Campaign for Jimmy Choo] ''BLOUINARTINFO''.</ref> and for [[Dior]] in 2013, ''1000 LIVES'', featuring [[Robert Pattinson]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Robert Pattinson Confirmed As New Face of Dior BY CHARLOTTE COWLES|url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2013/06/robert-pattinson-confirmed-as-new-face-of-dior.html|accessdate=12 June 2013}}</ref>

==Criticism==
Some critics have accused her of making [[heroin]]-use appear glamorous, and of pioneering a [[grunge]] style that later became popularized by youth fashion magazines such as ''[[The Face (magazine)|The Face]]'' and ''[[I-D]]''. However, in a 2002 interview with ''[[The Observer]]'', Goldin herself called the use of "[[heroin chic]]" to sell clothes and perfumes "reprehensible and evil."<ref>{{citation | title=The dark room | publisher=Guardian News and Media Limited|author= Sheryl Garratt|date=January 6, 2002|accessdate=2010-03-08|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/theobserver/2002/jan/06/features.magazine27|quote= "I never took pictures of people doing heroin to sell clothes. And I have a bit of a problem with it. Like this Dior campaign right now, where the girl is really dope-sick then she sprays Addiction perfume and suddenly she's high. I find that really reprehensible and evil."}}</ref>
Goldin admits to having a romanticized image of drug culture at a young age, but she soon saw the error in this ideal,  “I had a totally romantic notion of being a junkie. I wanted to be one.” Goldin’s substance usage stopped after she became intrigued with the idea of memory in her work, “When people talk about the immediacy in my work, that’s what its about: this need to remember and record every single thing” <ref>Goldin admits, “I had a totally romantic notion of being a junkie. I wanted to be one.” Goldin’s substance usage stopped after she became intrigued with the idea of memory in her work, “When people talk about the immediacy in my work, that’s what its about: this need to remember and record every single thing.”</ref>

===Censorship===
An exhibition of Goldin's work was censored in Brazil, two months before opening, due to its sexually explicit nature.<ref name="estadao.com.br">{{cite news|url=http://cultura.estadao.com.br/noticias/geral,cancelamento-de-exposicao-no-rio-deixa-artista-norte-americana-chocada,805090|title=Cancelamento de exposição no Rio deixa artista norte-americana chocada|author=Roberta Pennafort|location=Rio de Janeiro|newspaper=Estadão|language=Portuguese|date=30 November 2011|access-date=6 March 2016}}</ref> The main reason was the photographs containing sexual acts next to children.<ref name="estadao.com.br"/>  In Brazil, there is a law that prohibits the image of minors associated with pornography.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.planalto.gov.br/ccivil_03/leis/2003/L10.764.htm#art3|title=L10764|publisher=|language=Portuguese|access-date=6 March 2016}}</ref>
The sponsor of the exhibition, a cellphone company, claimed to be unaware of the content of Goldin's work and that there was a conflict between the work and its educational project. The curator of the Rio de Janeiro Museum of Modern Art changed the schedule in order to accommodate, in February 2012, the Goldin exhibition in Brazil.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/ilustrada/1013229-oi-futuro-cancela-mostra-da-artista-nan-goldin-no-rio.shtml |title=Oi Futuro cancela mostra da artista Nan Goldin no Rio |language=Portuguese |first=Silas |last=Martí |location=São Paulo |work=Folha de S. Paulo |date=29 November 2011 |access-date=6 March 2016}}</ref>

===Portrayal in film===
The photographs by the character Lucy Berliner, played by actress [[Ally Sheedy]] in the 1998 film ''[[High Art]]'', were based on those by Goldin.<ref>[http://www.metroactive.com/papers/metro/06.18.98/highart-9824.html Lisa Cholodenko's icy 'High Art' turns from chic comedy to humiliation] metroactive.com</ref>

The photographs shown  in the film, "Working Girls," (directed by Lizzie Borden, 1986) as taken by the lead character "Molly," were actually those of Nan Goldin.<ref>from the audio commentary by Lizzie Borden on the DVD of "Working Girls."</ref>

'''Betty Roodish Goodwin''', {{Post-nominals|country=CAN|OC}} (March 19, 1923 – December 1, 2008) was a [[Canada|Canadian]] printmaker, sculptor, painter, and installation artist.

== Early life ==

Born in [[Montreal]] the only child of [[Romanians|Romanian]] immigrants Betty loved to paint and draw  as a child, and was much encouraged by her mother to pursue art. Goodwin's father, a factory owner in Montreal, died when she was 9. After graduating from high school, she studied design at Valentine's Commercial School of Art in Montreal, then launched her career as a painter and printmaker in the late 1940s. In the 1960s, she enrolled in a [[printmaking]] class with [[Yves Gaucher]] at [[Sir George Williams University]] in [[Montreal]]. Dissatisfied with her work, she destroyed most of it and in 1968 she limited herself to drawing.<ref name="Johnson, Brian D 1998">Johnson, Brian D. "Body Language." ''Maclean's'' Vol. 111, no. 48 (Nov. 30, 1998): 88-89.</ref> 
She was married to Martin Goodwin, a civil engineer (d. 2008). Their son Paul died at 30 of a drug overdose.<ref name="Johnson, Brian D 1998" />

== Art ==

Betty Goodwin used a large variety of media, including [[collage]], sculpture, printmaking, painting and drawing, assemblage and etchings. Her subject matter almost always revolves around the human form and deals with it in a highly emotional way.<ref name="Johnson, Brian D 1998" /> Many of her ideas came from clusters of photographs, objects or drawings on the walls in her studio. She also used the “germ” of ideas that are left after being erased from a work.<ref name="Johnson, Brian D 1998" /> During the 1950's and 60's Goodwin painted still-lifes. She also depicted scenes of [[Jews in Montreal|Montreal's Jewish Community]]. She became interested in found objects, particularly how they represent traces of life. She created copper plate impressions of items of clothing to produce a series of [[etchings]], entitled ''Vest,'' which gained international attention. Goodwin created a series of wall hangings entitled ''Tarpaulin'' from 1972-`974, which she reworked to shape into sculptures and collages. Over a period of six years beginning in 1982, Goodwin explored the human form in her drawing series ''Swimmers,'' this project used graphite, oil pastels and charcoal on translucent Mylar. The large-scale drawings depict solitary floating or sinking bodies, suspended in space. In 1986, to show the interaction of human figures she created her series ''Carbon'' using charcoal and wax to create drawings.<ref>{{cite web|title=Betty Goodwin|url=http://www.gallery.ca/en/see/collections/artist.php?iartistid=2098|website=www.gallery.ca|publisher=National Gallery of Canada|accessdate=5 March 2015}}</ref>

== Career highlights ==

Goodwin's work has been exhibited in Montreal since the early 60s, with some significant solo shows. Other exhibitions have taken place elsewhere in Canada,  the U.S. and Europe. She was chosen to represent Canada in the [[Venice Biennial]] in 1995. In 1996, she was acknowledged with an exhibition at the [[National Gallery of Canada]], ''Betty Goodwin: Signs of Life''. In 2003, she was made an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]]. She died in December 2008 in Montreal.

Betty Goodwin's work is represented in many public collections including the [[Winnipeg Art Gallery]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Canadian Art, Winnipeg Art Gallery|url=http://wag.ca/art/collections/canadian-art/display,contemporary/52468|accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref> [[Musée d'art contemporain de Montréal]],<ref name=artefactsCanada>{{cite web|title=Artefacts Canada|url=http://www.rcip-chin.gc.ca/bd-dl/artefacts-eng.jsp?emu=en.artefacts:/ws/human/user/www/SearchForm&currLang=English|publisher=Canadian Heritage Information Network|accessdate=11 March 2015}}</ref> and the [[National Gallery of Canada]].<ref name=artefactsCanada />

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}}
'''Brita Granström''' (born 1969) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] artist who graduated from [[Konstfack]] Stockholm in 1994 and now lives and works between Great Britain and her homeland as a painter and illustrator.

==Painting==
In 2011 Granström's self-portrait ''Mother of Four'' was bought by The [[Ruth Borchard|Ruth Borchard Collection]]. A major solo exhibition ''Life in Landscape''  opened in London at Kings Place Gallery and toured to The University Gallery in Newcastle in 2012 under the title ''A Breath of Fresh Air''.<ref>http://www.thejournal.co.uk/culture/arts-culture-news/brita-granstrom-takes-plunge-new-7861877</ref> Recent exhibitions include ''The Night Swimmer'' (2014)<ref>https://www.northumbria.ac.uk/about-us/news-events/events/2014/09/brita-granstrom-the-night-swimmer/</ref> at The University Gallery, Newcastle upon Tyne and ''Sea Salt & Sourdough''<ref>http://www.openeyegallery.co.uk/events/sea-salt-sour-dough/</ref> (2015) at The Open Eye Gallery Edinburgh. She is represented by Thompson's Galleries Aldeburgh.

==Illustration==
Granström was shortlisted for the ALMA (Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award), in 2013 and 2014 for her children's books.<ref>http://www.picturehooks.org.uk/?page_id=663</ref> The ALMA is the largest children's literature award in the world.<ref>http://www.alma.se/en/about-the-award/</ref> She was elected as a Fellow of the English Association in May 2011.<ref>http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/english-association/fellowship/list</ref>
As a children's book illustrator, Granström often collaborates with her associate and partner, [[Mick Manning]]. They have produced various children's titles, such as ''Charlie's War Illustrated'' (Frances Lincoln) - winner of the 2014 English Association Award.<ref>http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/english-association/sigs/childrens-literature/authors/mickandbrita2013</ref> ''Taff in the WAAF'', their book about Manning's mother's war service for Bletchley Park, won the English Association Award in 2011.<ref>http://www.lovereading4kids.co.uk/book/8401/Taff-in-the-WAAF-by-Mick-Manning-Brita-Granstrom.html</ref>
In 1998 ''The Scotsman'' newspaper wrote: "Mick Manning and Brita Granström's approach to non-fiction for younger children has revolutionised our bookshelves"<ref>(Inside the Big Wide World of Stories. Lindsey Fraser. ''The Scotsman''. Tuesday 11 August 1998)</ref>
